awd_titl_txt: Mathematical Analysis of Novel Nonlinear Waves in Dissipative Optical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project theoretically investigates dissipative nonlinear wave systems in optics, which exhibit novel and counter-intuitive properties such as conservative-like behaviors and unidirectional wave propagation. Examples of such optical systems include certain advanced lasers supporting unidirectional light propagation along the edges of the laser cavity immune to scattering and disorder, which holds promise as an optical diode in the design of optical computers. Other examples include certain dissipative second-harmonic-generation systems featuring soliton families with continuous ranges of powers, which may be exploited for signal processing devices. Properties manifested in such systems are intriguing, and they will be investigated comprehensively in this project. Through advanced mathematical techniques and sophisticated numerical computations, new insight will be gained on the operation of these optical systems, so that their applications for optical diodes and nonlinear data processing can be assessed and optimized. 
 
The problems undertaken in this project are at the cutting edge of applied mathematics and optics. Mathematically, this project ventures into the unchartered territory of dissipative systems behaving like conservative systems, which opens new research directions in the study of nonlinear waves. On the physical side, these studies will lead to better understanding of next-generation laser devices, which will have direct applications to many branches of optics and photonics. Educationally, graduate students will be trained, and undergraduate honors thesis and undergraduate summer research will be supervised, so that this project will help train young talents in the STEM fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, the PI investigated a number of novel nonlinear wave phenomena in both dissipative and conservative optical systems modeled by nonlinear partial differential equations. In the dissipative case, he studied the counterintuitive phenomenon of nonlinear optical media with certain complex refractive index profiles admitting soliton families with continuous power ranges. He also constructed new families of non-parity-time-symmetric complex potentials which feature real spectra. In the conservative case, he studied nonlinear effects on linear topologically protected states and the intriguing dynamics of rogue wave events that appear unexpectedly. By developing analytical and numerical methodologies on the underlying mathematical models, deep understanding of these novel nonlinear optical phenomena was reached. Such enhanced understanding could lead to new insights and predictions of nonlinear wave phenomena in physical systems. The analytical methodologies developed would also enrich the techniques of applied mathematics.

Specifically, the following results were obtained.

1. The PI analytically explained the counterintuitive phenomenon of the existence of soliton families in dissipative nonlinear Schroedinger models with certain non-parity-time-symmetric complex potentials in both one and two spatial dimensions. By utilizing a conservation law of the underlying non-Hamiltonian wave system, he converted the complex soliton equation into a new real system. For this new real system, he perturbatively constructed a continuous family of low-amplitude solitons bifurcating from a linear eigenmode to all orders of the small soliton amplitude. Hence, the intriguing emergence of soliton families in this dissipative nonlinear system is analytically explained. 

2. With the supersymmetry method and the pseudo-Hermiticity method, the PI and collaborators found new families of non-parity-time-symmetric complex potentials with real spectra. Different from previous derivations, this derivation does not utilize discrete eigenmodes of base potentials. As a result, these new potentials feature explicit analytical expressions which contain free functions. 

3. The PI and collaborators investigated both theoretically and experimentally the effect of nonlinearity on topologically protected linear interface modes in a photonic Su–Schrieffer–Heeger (SSH) lattice. It was shown that under either focusing or defocusing nonlinearity, this linear topological mode of the SSH lattice would turn into a family of topological gap solitons. These solitons are stable. However, they exhibit only a low amplitude and power and are thus weakly nonlinear, even when the bandgap of the SSH lattice is wide. As a consequence, if the initial beam has modest or high power, it will either delocalize, or evolve into a soliton not belonging to the family of topological gap solitons. These theoretical predictions were observed in experiments with optically induced SSH-type photorefractive lattices.

4. The PI and collaborators theoretically and experimentally demonstrated that a probe beam at one wavelength, although exhibiting a weak nonlinear response on its own, can be modulated and controlled by a pump beam at another wavelength in plasmonic nanosuspensions, leading to ring-shaped pattern generation.

5. The PI and collaborators also developed a number of analytical techniques for the derivation of rogue wave solutions in integrable systems by the bilinear method, such as a new treatment of dimensional reduction and a new parameterization, which significantly simplified the bilinear procedure and allowed more complex problems to be treated. They applied these techniques and obtained explicit rogue waves in several optically important integrable systems, such as the NLS equation, the derivative NLS equations, the Manakov system, and the three-wave interaction system. In addition, they showed that these different integrable systems exhibit universal rogue wave patterns. These rogue patterns comprise fundamental rogue waves arranged in shapes such as a triangle, pentagon and heptagon, with a possible lower-order rogue wave at the center. These patterns appear when one of the internal parameters in rogue waves gets large. Analytically, they showed that these patterns are determined by the root structures of the Yablonskii-Vorob’ev polynomial hierarchy through a linear transformation.

On this project, the PI published 15 refereed journal articles. He also trained one postdoc and one undergraduate student on it.
